title: Did Steph Curry and the Golden State Warriors Really Change the NBA?
text:
The biggest change in the last decade is the number of threes NBA teams are taking. Before, 3-pointers were not the way NBA teams won games, but now, if you want to win, teams look to outscore your opponent by 3.
Even though it has been proven that you can win an NBA championship by relying on hitting 3s, there are NBA fans who hate this style of play and believe the NBA is unwatchable.
NBA analysts believe Stephen Curry and the Golden State Warriors are to blame for this 3-point revolution. They were the first NBA team to win an NBA championship in 2015 by being a 3-point-heavy team. In addition, their star backcourt duo was given the nickname the Splash Brothers because of how good they were at hitting shots from 3.
Yet, I believe there is another player and team that changed the NBA.
That is James Harden and the Houston Rockets, The Golden State Warriors’ main competitor from 2015 to 2019.
You probably think I am crazy. There is no way the Houston Rockets shot as many or even more threes than the Golden State Warriors, but trust me, you will be surprised.
Here is a facet wrap comparing the number of 3-point attempts by the Golden State Warriors and the Houston Rockets from 2014 to 2019.


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(ggrepel)
library(ggalt)
logs <- read_csv("data/Warriors_Rockets_3_Attempts.csv")
logsGOLHOU <- read_csv("data/Warriors_Rockets_3_Attempts.csv")
leagueaverage <- read_csv("data/Average_3_per_season_Real.csv")
logs24 <- read_csv("data/NBA_2023_2024_STATS.csv")
ggplot() +
  geom_line(
    data = logs,
    aes(x = Year, y = `3P Attempts`, group = Team)
  ) +
  geom_point(
    data = logs,
    aes(x = Year, y = `3P Attempts`),
    size = 2  
  ) +
  scale_y_continuous(limits = c(20, 50)) +  
  facet_wrap(~Team, scales = "free_y", ncol = 4) +  
  labs(
    title = "The NBA media lied to you",
    subtitle = "James Harden and the Rockets transformed the NBA's 3-point game",
    y = "3 Point Attempts", x = "Year",
    caption = "By: Daniel Mahoney | Source: nba.com"
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 18, face = "bold"), 
    plot.background = element_rect(fill = "white"),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 14),  
    axis.title = element_text(size = 10),  
    axis.text = element_text(size = 9),  
    strip.text = element_text(size = 10, face = "bold"),  
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),  
    panel.grid.major = element_line(color = "gray", size = 0.2)  
  )









The numbers even surprised me because when the Warriors won their first NBA championship in 2015, the narrative was this Golden State team was going to ruin the NBA, and no one was taking threes like them.
However, in 2015, the Houston Rockets were first in 3-point attempts with 32.7 3s per game, while the Warriors shot 27 3s per game.
Based on how people talk, you would think the Golden State Warriors were the first NBA team in history to take 40 3s per game, but the Houston Rockets were first to do so in 2017 as they attempted 40.3 shots from long distance.
From 2014 to 2019, the Warriors never shot over 40 3s per game. The Houston Rockets attempted 40 3s per game in three straight seasons.
The only time the Golden State Warriors shot more 3s than the Houston Rockets during the James Harden era was in 2016. This season, the Warriors won 73 games but lost in the NBA finals to the Cleveland Cavaliers.
In 2016, the Warriors shot 31.6 3s per game, and the Rockets shot 30.9 3s per game. This shows that in the one year, the Warriors shot more 3s than the Rockets, there was still no difference.
Just looking at this facet wrap gives you a good idea that the Rockets were more of a 3-point-heavy team than the Warriors, but there is more.
Here is a line chart showing the amount of 3s the Warriors and Rockets took and comparing it to the league average for that season.


Code
GOL <- logsGOLHOU |> filter(Team == "Golden State")
HOU <- logsGOLHOU |> filter(Team == "Houston")
ggplot() +
  geom_line(
    data = GOL, 
    aes(x = Year, y = `3P Attempts`, color = "Golden State"),  
  ) + 
  geom_line(
    data = HOU, 
    aes(x = Year, y = `3P Attempts`, color = "Houston"),  
  ) + 
  geom_line(
    data = leagueaverage, 
    aes(x = Year, y = `3P Attempts`, color = "League Average"),  
  ) +
  geom_point(
    data = GOL, 
    aes(x = Year, y = `3P Attempts`, color = "Golden State"),  
    size = 2, 
    shape = 16
  ) +
  geom_point(
    data = HOU, 
    aes(x = Year, y = `3P Attempts`, color = "Houston"),  
    size = 2, 
    shape = 16
  ) +
  geom_point(
    data = leagueaverage, 
    aes(x = Year, y = `3P Attempts`, color = "League Average"),  
    size = 2, 
    shape = 16
  ) +
  scale_color_manual(
    values = c("Golden State" = "blue", "Houston" = "red", "League Average" = "black")
  ) +
  scale_y_continuous(limits = c(20, 50)) +
  labs(
    y = "Three Point Attempts", x = "Year",
    title = "No one took threes like the Houston Rockets",
    subtitle = "The NBA followed in the footsteps of the Houston Rockets",
    caption = "Source: basketball reference | By Daniel Mahoney",  
    color = "Label"  
  ) +
  geom_text(
    aes(x = 2017, y = 40.7, label = "40.3"),
    color = "black",
    size = 4,
    vjust = -1,  
    hjust = 0.5
  ) +
  geom_text(
    aes(x = 2018, y = 42.7, label = "42.3"),
    color = "black",
    size = 4,
    vjust = -1,  
    hjust = 0.5
  ) +
  geom_text(
    aes(x = 2019, y = 45.8, label = "45.4"),
    color = "black",
    size = 4,
    vjust = -1,  
    hjust = 0.5
  ) +
  geom_text(
    aes(x = 2014, y = 20.9, label = "21.5"),
    color = "black",
    size = 4,
    vjust = -1,  
    hjust = 0.5
  ) +
  geom_text(
    aes(x = 2015, y = 22, label = "22.4"),
    color = "black",
    size = 4,
    vjust = -1,  
    hjust = 0.5
  ) +
  geom_text(
    aes(x = 2016, y = 23.7, label = "24.1"),
    color = "black",
    size = 4,
    vjust = -1,  
    hjust = 0.5
  ) +
  geom_text(
    aes(x = 2017, y = 26.6, label = "27"),
    color = "black",
    size = 4,
    vjust = -1,  
    hjust = 0.5
  ) +
   geom_text(
    aes(x = 2018, y = 28.6, label = "29"),
    color = "black",
    size = 4,
    vjust = -1,  
    hjust = 0.5
  ) +
  geom_text(
    aes(x = 2019, y = 31.5, label = "32"),
    color = "black",
    size = 4,
    vjust = -1,  
    hjust = 0.5
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 18, face = "bold"), 
    plot.background = element_rect(fill = "white"),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 14),  
    axis.title = element_text(size = 10),  
    axis.text = element_text(size = 9),  
    strip.text = element_text(size = 10, face = "bold"),  
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),  
    panel.grid.major = element_line(color = "gray", size = 0.2)  
  )









I created this line chart to show that the Rockets were always way above the league average when it came to 3-point attempts.
The other reason is I wanted to highlight that the NBA had its biggest jump in 3-point attempts when the Houston Rockets were attempting 40 3s per game.
In 2017, the average amount of 3s attempted in the NBA was 27, but in 2019, that number increased to 32 3s per game, and the Houston Rockets took 45.3, which is insane.
The question you are probably asking is why did the Houston Rockets take so many 3s?
In 2017, the Houston Rockets hired Mike D’Antoni. D’Antoni is known for building an identity on offense based on the players he has. He was the head coach of the seven seconds or less Phoenix Suns.
Mike D’Antoni realized the Rockets most efficient offense would be running through James Harden. That is why James Harden became one of the most ball-dominant players in the NBA, and the Rockets filled their rosters with guys who would stand at the 3-point line and be ready to shoot when James Harden passed them the ball.
This style of play of one player dominating the ball and taking so many 3-pointers was criticized, but it led to success.
As the Houston Rockets were a top 2 offense in the NBA for three straight seasons, combine this with the Rockets trading for Chris Paul in the summer of 2017, and they became the second scariest team in the NBA.
With Mike as the Rockets head coach, Houston went to the Conference Finals in 2018 but lost to the Warriors in seven games. James Harden won the Regular Season MVP in 2018, and in 2019, Harden had one of the most historic scoring seasons in NBA history. He averaged 36.1 points per game.
The NBA saw this success and thought this was the best chance of winning. Which is the ultimate compliment to James Harden. He was so good that the rest of the NBA had to adjust to his play style.
I am not mad at the Houston Rockets because they realized that with the players they had and with James Harden being one of the best NBA players in the league. This style of play would be their best chance of winning a championship.
The question I have. Does 3-point shooting lead to wins in the NBA?
This bubble chart, with the dot size scaled by the number of wins, shows that the best NBA teams have their own identity that helps them win basketball games.


Code
GoodTeams <- logs24 |>  
  filter(Wins > 49)
Boston <- GoodTeams |>  
  filter(Wins > 62)
Denver <- GoodTeams |>  
  filter(Team == "Denver Nuggets")
ggplot() +
  geom_point(
    data = logs24,
    aes(
      x = `3P Attempts`, 
      y = `3P Percentage`, 
      size = Wins
    ),
    alpha = 0.6  
  ) + 
  geom_point(
    data = GoodTeams, 
    aes(
      x = `3P Attempts`, 
      y = `3P Percentage`, 
      size = Wins
    ),
    alpha = 0.6,  
    color = "blue"
  ) + 
  geom_point(
    data = Boston, 
    aes(
      x = `3P Attempts`, 
      y = `3P Percentage`, 
      size = Wins
    ),
    alpha = 0.6,  
    color = "green"
  ) + 
  geom_point(
    data = Denver, 
    aes(
      x = `3P Attempts`, 
      y = `3P Percentage`, 
      size = Wins
    ),
    alpha = 0.6,  
    color = "#FFCC00"
  ) + 
  geom_text_repel(
    data = GoodTeams,  
    aes(
      x = `3P Attempts`, 
      y = `3P Percentage`, 
      label = Team
    ),
    box.padding = 0.5,
    point.padding = 0.5,
    max.overlaps = 10
  ) +
  scale_size_continuous(
    breaks = c(45, 50, 55, 60),
    labels = c("45", "50", "55", "60"),
    range = c(2, 6)
  ) +
  labs(
    x = "Three Point Attempts",
    y = "Three Point Percentage",
    title = "While NBA teams are taking more 3s",
    subtitle = "The most successful NBA teams have an identity shaped by their players",
    caption = "Source: nba.com | By Daniel Mahoney",
    size = "Wins"
  ) +
  geom_text(
    aes(x = 42.3, y = 38.3, label = "NBA"),
    color = "black",
    size = 4,
    vjust = -1,
    hjust = 0.5
  ) +
  geom_text(
    aes(x = 42.3, y = 38.1, label = "Champs"),
    color = "black",
    size = 4,
    vjust = -1,
    hjust = 0.5
  ) +
   geom_text(
    aes(x = 40.7, y = 38.1, label = "Most 3s"),
    color = "black",
    size = 4,
    vjust = -1,
    hjust = 0.5
  ) +
  geom_text(
    aes(x = 31.5, y = 36.95, label = "Fewest 3s"),
    color = "black",
    size = 4,
    vjust = -1,
    hjust = 0.5
  ) +
  guides(size = guide_legend(title = "Wins", override.aes = list(color = "#333333"))) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 18, face = "bold"), 
    plot.background = element_rect(fill = "white"),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 14),  
    axis.title = element_text(size = 10),  
    axis.text = element_text(size = 9),  
    strip.text = element_text(size = 10, face = "bold"),  
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),  
    panel.grid.major = element_line(color = "gray", size = 0.2)  
  )









First, you will realize that the NBA champions, Boston Celtics, won 64 games last year and shot 42.5 3s per game.
This may frustrate you. However, what I am going to tell you is that taking 3s gives the Celtics the best chance of winning games.
Everyone in that starting lineup can shoot 3s. Boston was second in the league in 3-point percentage, shooting 38.8% from 3. This shows that Boston is good at hitting 3-pointers and playing the analytical game works in the Celtic’s favor.
However, taking 3s does not work for everyone. Look at the Denver Nuggets, who took the least amount of 3s in the NBA. They won 57 games in the regular season last year.
That is because Denver runs their offense through the three-time MVP. Nikola Jokic who is not reliant on hitting threes.
Jokic relies on his incredible post-up game and passing to get him and his teammates easy shots in the paint. Even though the Nuggets did not take 3s, they were sixth in paint points, scoring 52.8 points in the paint. This is a different style of play than the Boston Celtics.
The point is even though the NBA has become reliant on hitting shots from deep, the best NBA teams have their own identity based on the talent on their roster.
You can not copy and do what the best does because you can not outplay the best at their own game.
The most successful NBA teams have their own identity. For example, the Houston Rockets in 2018 and 2019, led by prime James Harden, the one who really changed the NBA.

title: Were the Phoenix Suns Playoff-Worthy in 2014?
text:
The 2013-2014 NBA season was filled with unforgettable storylines: LeBron James played his final season with the Miami Heat, and the San Antonio Spurs beat the Heat to win their fifth NBA Championship in a Finals rematch.
However, people need to remember how competitive the Western Conference was during this dynamic NBA season. Eight teams won 49 games or more, and the 9th seed won 48 games but missed the playoffs.
That team was the Phoenix Suns. In a shocking turnaround, the Suns went from a sad 25 wins in 2013 to an impressive 48 wins in 2014, surpassing expectations.
This team should have made the 2014 playoffs.
The numbers tell the story!
Let’s start with net rating, a stat in the NBA that calculates point differential across 100 possessions. Good teams have a higher net rating, while bad teams have a lower net rating.
Here is the net rating of every Western Conference team during the 2013-2014 NBA season.


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(gt)
library(ggrepel)
library(ggalt)
library(ggbump)
logs14 <- read_csv("data/NBA_2013_2014_STATS.csv")
rankingsnba <- read_csv("data/Standing_By_Dates_West.csv")
WestNet <- logs14 |>
  filter(Conference == "West") |>
  group_by(Team) |>
  summarise(
    `Net Rating` = mean(NETRTG),
    Wins = sum(W),  
    Losses = sum(L)      
  ) |>
  select(Team, Wins, Losses, `Net Rating`) |>
  arrange(desc(Wins)) 
WestNet |> 
 ungroup() |> 
  gt() |> 
  tab_header(
    title = "According to net rating, Phoenix was a top 8 team in the West",
    subtitle = "The Suns posted a better net rating than both the 7th seed and 8th seed in the West"
  ) |>
  tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", weight = "bold", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("title")
  ) |>
  tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("subtitle")) |>
  tab_source_note(
    source_note = md("**By:** Daniel Mahoney  |  **Source:** nba.com: Teams Advanced | Stats | NBA.com")
  ) |>
  tab_style(
    locations = cells_column_labels(columns = everything()),
    style = list(
      cell_borders(sides = "bottom", weight = px(3)),
      cell_text(weight = "bold", size = 12)
    )
  ) |>
  opt_row_striping() |>
  opt_table_lines("none") |>
  tab_style(
    style = list(
      cell_fill(color = "#00538C"),
      cell_text(color = "white" )
    ),
    locations = cells_body(
      rows = Team == "Dallas Mavericks"
    )
  ) |>
  tab_style(
    style = list(
      cell_fill(color = "#00285E"),
      cell_text(color = "white")
    ),
    locations = cells_body(
      rows = Team == "Memphis Grizzlies"
    )
  ) |>
  tab_style(
    style = list(
      cell_fill(color = "#E56020"),
      cell_text(color = "white")
    ),
    locations = cells_body(
      rows = Team == "Phoenix Suns"
    )
  ) |>
  tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "green", weight = "bold"),
    locations = cells_body(
      columns = c(`Net Rating`),
      rows = `Net Rating` > 0
    )
  ) |>
tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "red", weight = "normal"),
    locations = cells_body(
      columns = c(`Net Rating`),
      rows = `Net Rating` < 0
    )
  )

Phoenix finished with the seventh-best net rating in the Western Conference in 2014, posting a rating of 2.6. This was higher than the Memphis Grizzlies and the Dallas Mavericks, two teams that ultimately made the playoffs.
In the last ten years, teams in the West that have been among the Top 8 in net rating in the conference have made the Western Conference playoffs 88.8% of the time.
The Suns’ success was driven by their elite offense, ranking in the Top 10 in several offensive categories.
They averaged 105.2 points per game, placing 7th in the NBA, and recorded an offensive rating of 108.2, which ranked 8th in the league. Offensive rating measures a team’s efficiency, showing how many points they score per 100 possessions.


Code
Points <- logs14 |>
  group_by(Team) |>
  summarise(
    `Points Per Game` = mean(PTS),         
    `Offensive Rating` = mean(OFFRTG),     
  )  
PointsSuns <- logs14 |>
  filter(Team == "Phoenix Suns") |>
  group_by(Team) |>
  summarise(
    `Points Per Game` = mean(PTS),         
    `Offensive Rating` = mean(OFFRTG),     
  )

  geom_point(data = Points, aes(x = `Points Per Game`, y = `Offensive Rating`), color="#768188") +
  geom_point(data = PointsSuns, aes(x = `Points Per Game`, y = `Offensive Rating`), color="#FBAF6F", size = 2.5) +

    hjust = 0.5,

  ) +

  ) +

    caption = "Source: nba.com | By Daniel Mahoney"
  ) +
  theme(

The Arizona-based team was also highly efficient in its shooting, ranking 8th in both field goal and three-point percentage. Shooting 46.3% from the field and 37.2% from beyond the arc.


Code
ShootingPer <- logs14 |>
  group_by(Team) |>
  summarise(
    `Field Goal Percentage` = mean(`FG%`, na.rm = TRUE),

In 2014, only three teams finished in the Top 10 in points per game, offensive rating, field goal percentage, and three-point percentage. Two teams, the San Antonio Spurs and the Dallas Mavericks, made the playoffs, while the third team, the Phoenix Suns, missed the playoffs.
Another factor that needs to be talked about is how tough the West was compared to the East.
What if the Suns were in the East? Would they be able to stand out?
This bubble chart, with the dot size scaled by the number of wins, shows that the Suns would have been exceptional in the East, especially compared to the teams that made the Eastern Conference playoffs (the teams that are labeled).

Only one team in the East had a better offensive rating than the Phoenix Suns, the Miami Heat, who had the star trio of LeBron James, Dwyane Wade, and Chris Bosh.
Additionally, it is worth noting that the third-seeded Toronto Raptors finished with the same number of wins as the Suns. Meanwhile, the Atlanta Hawks finished with 38 wins but still made the NBA Playoffs as the 8th seed.
What is interesting is that the Suns finished with the same number of wins as the Raptors. Even though the Suns played 52 games against the West and 30 games against the East, the team from Canada played 52 games against the East and 30 games against the West.
Imagine if Phoenix was in the East, and 52 of their opponents were against teams in the East. They would have easily surpassed 48 wins.
However, the Phoenix Suns did enough to make the playoffs in the West. There were stretches during the season when they were in the playoff picture.

The Suns picked the worst possible time to slump, losing three of their final four games. The losses to the Dallas Mavericks and Memphis Grizzlies proved to cost them. On April 12th, Phoenix fell to the Mavericks 101-98, followed by a 97-91 loss to the Grizzlies just two days later.
Those two teams were competing with the Suns for playoff positioning, and if Phoenix had won both games, we would have seen this Suns team in the 2014 NBA playoffs.
